text: I got a 2020 Honda CR-V a few weeks ago. First vehicle I've had with Android Auto support (or Car Play but I haven't owned a iPhone since the iPhone 4, just personal preference).Anyways when I first got it I couldn't not get Android Auto to work. I tried everything I could find online about the problem and you can find plenty of people that have/had trouble getting it to work in their Honda CR-V (ironic since the infotainment system runs on android). Tried doing a full factory reset on the infotainment system, turning on USB debugging in dev settings, and the 2 dif USB type C to USB type A cable I had. No matter it would not work. My phone would charge when plugged in but that's it. A message is supposed to pop up on the infotainment system asking if you want to enable android auto.I bought this cable as a last resort. I made sure to get a USB 2.0 and NOT a USB 3.0 type C to USB type A cable. Didn't think it would make a difference. Got in the car, turned it on, plugged the cable into the car, then into my phone, and BAM the "do you want to enable android auto" message instantly pops up on the infotainment system. And it works perfectly. Love it.
title: Couldn't get Android Auto to work in my new car, this cable did the trick!

text: I recently purchased the Amazon Basics USB A to USB C cable and wanted to share my experience with fellow shoppers. I haven't experienced any connectivity issues or data transfer problems so far, which is crucial when it comes to cables.However, one notable drawback of this cable is its stiff jacket. The cable's outer covering feels rigid and inflexible, making it a bit challenging to maneuver and position as desired. Although this stiffness can be attributed to the cable's durability, it may be a point of concern for those seeking a more flexible and pliable option.That being said, if you're primarily looking for a durable cable that can withstand some wear and tear, this might be a suitable choice for you. text: This charging system really is very useful. This is the one single Amazon find that I have proselytized to others and encouraged them to use.  I've used this type of charging system for years.  I love it.  This particular order was to replace a couple cables and plugs that have eventually disappeared or were damaged over the years. I hesitated to write this review; not because it's bad --  the product is great. But because i find the super-gushing reviews where everything is perfect (insert multiple exclamation points!!) to be sus.  And today I'm writing a review that I'm afraid will sound gushing. The two parts are (a) the metal head/plug that stays in your phone, plus (b) charging cable with a magnetic connection the little metal head. The system includes multiple small metal heads for USB-C, iPhone Lightning, and micro-USB. These insert into the phone or device and stay there, although you can remove them at any time if needed. The cable has a magnetic end that automatically snaps to the head to connect and charge it.Pro:- One-handed operation -- Really simple & easy to connect the charge cable to your phone, every time.  You can do it one handed if needed; just get the magnetic end of the cable close and it snaps in place. I can plug in the cable in the dark or while bouncing down the road in a car.- One cable to rule them all --  I have devices that use UBS-C, and devices that use Apple Lightning and others with Micro-USB.  This system allows me to use one cable for all three. I only need to carry one cable rather than three cables for three (or more) devices.- Prevents damage to charge port -- The magnetic connection is strong enough to hold the weight of my phone if i lift it gently, but it will become disconnected if I happen to trip over the cable or pull hard for whatever reason.  This helps to prevent damage to the phone's connection port that can occur if a normal cable is pushed or pulled too hard to the side while connected to the port.- reduces wear & limits pocket lint from clogging the phone's charge port -- yah, this is minor; since the head/plug stays in your phone, it fills the charging port and mostly blocks dirt, dirt, lint, water, whatever from getting into the charge port.Con:- Charging only -- These cables do not include transfer data. ...on the plus side, you can connect to a public (eg: airport) charge port without fear of your data being accessed.  At least not through the cable.- Limits Fast Charging -- Occasionally, my phone has performed fast-charging through the magnetic connection, but not usually.  Personally, that is fine with me. Normally I'm near a charger long enough (overnight) that I don't utilize the fast-charging feature.- Sometimes need to remove the head/plug -- You may need to remove the metal head before taking off a phone case.  but you would need to unplug a normal cable too.  Likewise, if you have to borrow a normal cable, then you would also need to remove the head.Thanks for reading; hope this helps someone!
title: Writing this review is painful.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2023

text: These cables are the answer to my charging woes. Over the years I’ve gone through countless pricey cords that invariably get bent, frayed and peel at the weaker part -where the cord meets the plugs- and I wished that multidirectional cords like these had been available all along. No more bending, fraying and having to purchase spare cords in the foreseeable future.The pack comes with two 78” long, fiber-encased (not plastic) and very flexible cords, as well as two sets of three different tips (six in total) to use with pretty much all kinds of phones, tablets and other electronics, and the same cord can be used will all of them as the connections are magnetized. I leave the plugs attached to my Samsung phone and iPad, so it’s extremely easy and convenient to simply attach the magnet end of the cord to the plugs, without having to wiggle them in place. These cords charge at roughly the same speed than regular cords do, so I have not noticed a significant difference.I cannot tell how durable they are, but I’ve been using them daily for weeks and they remain in pristine condition, with no noticeable deterioration. I do recommend this product.
title: Charging cables with an advantage.

text: Maybe it worked a little TOO well, maybe it was user error and I wasn't supposed to use it on my earbud case--I don't know. All I know is that I bought this charger as a temporary replacement for my earbud case since the original charger stopped working (and ironically, the charger cables on the official brand site are completely sold out, hence turning to Amazon for a generic one). I have an older, nearly falling apart version of the earbuds that uses a different charger type, and I charge it with a generic charging cable--I haven't had a problem in the 2 years I've been using it. Hence my optimism doing the same for the new earbuds. I opened it as soon as it arrived and everything seemed great. I plugged it into my case and it charged just fine; in fact, it was just what I needed at the start. Cue a couple hours later.I unplugged the case, as it was fully charged, and was using my earbuds when all of a sudden--after about an hour of it being unplugged--there was a LOUD pop, sparks flew out of the case, and it began to smoke. I hurried and disposed of the case because obviously, but was confused because HOW??? The only reasons that come to mind is that the charger and earbud case just weren't compatible or I was sent a faulty charging cable. I don't know, I'm not a battery expert, but I DO know that lithium batteries aren't supposed to randomly explode within an hour of charging them. Just exercise EXTREME caution and monitor your devices if you do decide to purchases this charger, because no one wants lithium batteries to randomly explode in their house.
title: Could potentially cause your lithium battery to explode
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 21, 2023

text: The description says it will work with “any Type-C enabled device”. Maybe I’m just misunderstanding what “any Type-C enabled device” actually is. I would like a longer charging cable for my iPad Pro and I gambled, since it says it will work with another Apple product, (the MacBook), and lost. The cable might just as well be a piece of string with usb plugs. There is no response of any kind when I plug it in. Even an off brand lightning cable will say “this device may not work with this cable “. Returning it would just be more trouble than it’s worth. Giving it two stars is working on the assumption that it may actually work on “any Type-C enabled device”... except the iPad Pro! So, be careful and don’t get your hopes up. Especially if you want to use it for an Apple product.To be fair I could not find anywhere it said it WOULD work with the iPad Pro. 🌟🌟UPDATE: I does work! The charging cable that came with the iPad is instantly recognized so when I plugged the new one in and it didn’t immediately work I made the mistaken assumption that my new iPad just wouldn’t recognize this Non-Apple cord. It actually takes about 7-8 seconds to wake up and begin charging with this generic cable.So, 7 seconds is just fine with me and assuming it won’t burn out like the old Lightning cables did.I couldn’t be happier.If you found my review helpful, please let Amazon know by clicking the helpful button below!
title: It might just as well be a piece of string with usb plugs! UPDATED POSITIVE REVIEW!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 12, 2019

text: Amazon Basics USB Type-C to USB-A 2.0 Male Charger Cable, 3 Feet (0.9 Meters), White. These 3-foot white USB Type-C to USB-A 2.0 Male charger cables can connect USB-C enabled devices (MacBook, Chromebook Pixel, Galaxy Note 7, etc.) with standard USB-A enabled devices (laptops, hard drives, power banks, wall/car chargers, etc.). They are handy for charging, powering USB-C enabled devices, as well as syncing data, photos, and music. They boast up to 480 Mbps data transfer speed; power output up to 5V, 3 Amp.  They are reversible; the user can easily insert the Type-C connector into any Type-C enabled device (does not matter which side is up). And they are certified by USB-IF to be compliant with USB 2.0 Standard.Well, these are handy things to have  around in a world where they are frequently misplaced. Was once talking to a hotel maid who remarked that she often found them under beds, etc.  I lose them occasionally, usually at high-stress moments when  they’re really needed.  Glad to have a few. Like the 3-foot length for my car.

text: Amazon basic brand is my go to brand for electronic accessories for its vetted quality. Bought 6 foot cord already and now buying more to lay around the house at my desk, sofa, recliner, and in my car. Easier than carrying one set of cords around. Found the 10 foot cord was too long which reduces charging speed, especially when paired up with lower mAh charger, or does not power the device at all. Pair a 10 footer only if you have a high capacity charger. Forget about QI wireless charging which have a higher charging demand. Disadvantage of using cords with plastic type covers vs braided type covers is that they are easier to tangle and inserts wrinkles went tightly wrapped and folded in. I installed a Velcro cord wrap you can buy at a home improvement store to avoid wrinkles when wrapping and storing the cord. The connector tip do break off if you step on them.

text:
I recently got a new phone that uses a USB Type-C charger. All of my other devices used a micro USB, so I suddenly found myself without any spare USB cables that would work for my phone. This AmazonBasics cord, which has a USB Type-C on one end and USB-A on the other, works perfectly for me to charge my phone using my computer at work. It also works well with the 
  
AmazonBasics 60W 6-Port USB Charger - Black







  
  
    , which is what I use to charge all my devices overnight. The 6-foot cord gives ample room to move around while the phone is charging. I will say the charging speeds don't compare to the official Google charger that came with my Pixel, but as I'm basically using this as a backup charger, anyway, it's not a big deal.I have had one problem, and I don't know if it's computer or cord related: The first time I plugged this into my computer, my screen immediately snapped to thin, colorful, horizontal lines. My music kept playing in the background, but the screen was useless. I had to force shut down, and when I restarted, everything was fine. I've used the cord (in the same port on the same computer) multiple times since then with no trouble, but I thought it was worth mentioning.
title: Good back-up cord for USB Type-C devices

text: USB C cables for charging, and even not so, are active cables, they have a chip in them that allows it recognize its position and what it can do.  So, I am very skeptical about $1 USB-C cables, not just that it would work, but continue to work after purchase and not destroy your gadget now or later.  Given the cost of the gadget,  and that cables last over the useful life of the gadget, getting a brand name I can hold accountable is better if not formally USB C certified.ProsI tested these cables using a Ruideng 25C and my phones Turbo Charger QC 2.0 mode.  The cable allowed current to 2.4A, as rated, and engaged the QC 2.0 mode, and works bidirectionally, as expected.  I used the cable for charging for over 1 week then installed it to charge a mounted phone on my car, but charging is only non-turbo modeQuality build by reputable brand, braided firm materialNo Cons

text: I purchased this Amazon Basics USB C cable for use with my Nintendo Switch Pro controller.  I play with the controller plugged in because not allowing a battery to cycle full to empty extends its life (Modern batteries don't need to be "power cycled" regularly like older batteries did.)  I needed a cable that was long enough to reach the wall but not so long that it was a mess of cords that became a hassle.  I also needed one that was powerful enough to charge the controller.  I tested the controller by playing with it for a couple of days while not plugged in, and the battery level in the system didn't appear to go down any, so I couldn't judge exactly how fast this cable charges, but it charged it well enough for my use because the level has stayed full during my uses.Overall, I didn't find any flaws in using this Amazon Basics USB C cable with my Nintendo Switch Pro controller and highly recommend it for that application.  5/5 stars

text: I have had these cables before, and I do like the Amazon Basics line of goods in general.These are hearty in the way they are made, and last a lot longer than any other cords I've owned.However, the one draw back is their rigidity, they don't bend or flex easily. If you hold your phone while its plugged in, it will continually drop the cable on you. The rigidity doesn't allow the cable to bend as you move, and forces the connector to flex back and forth making it wiggle out of the port.I have one of these in my car, wired into the dash and comes out at the phone mount. The setup is static and the wire doesn't wiggle free. So, for that setup its perfect.  But I have another loose wire in the cab for the passenger, and you have to hold the cable to keep it from coming out.I also use another for connecting a laptop to my network. Its fine because it doesn't move and wiggle out.
title: Great longevity, but a little too rigid for hand holding.

text: Not the best of the Amazonbasics cables i've used.  Bought it as a secondary cable for use in my car.  Whenever I plug it into my cell phone (ZTE MAX) the phone continually "dings" on and off because the cable is very loose in the USB C port.  The OEM cable does not cause this to happen, neither does the OEM cable from a Samsung phone I have.I  have several of this brand of charger cable for my Apple products, both with the 30 pin connector and the lightning connector, and always recommend them over any other brand including Apple's branded cables, as these have worked just as good for a fraction of the price, and honestly, have lasted longer than the Apple OEM ones. Which makes me think that this is just an isolated issue.I did not return it because if I use it as a desktop charger, where it's not moving in the vehicle, it does not chime on and off all to often.  I assuming that its because it's stationary and the plug is not wiggling around.I would still recommend buying Amazonbasics cables over the OEM for any manufacturer, and especially over the 100's of non OEM brands from any retailer, as they not only cost more, but in my experciance are subpar, and not orth buying even at 1/2 the cost of the Amazon basics.

Every single USB port remained functional after I plugged it in.I've been looking for a cable like that. text: "You get what you pay for" is a saying for a reason. This is really affordable, and the USB-A/USB-C cables I received with my Android devices are ABSURDLY short, so the long cord was something I desperately wanted to find. But a few weeks ago, a little under a year after I bought it, this cord stopped being effective at charging, and my devices almost always either 1) don't think they're plugged in, or 2) warn me that they are charging much slower than they should be -- and that warning generally means that they are charging so slowly that they are draining the battery faster than they are charging it, so the phone will inevitably die. I have to contort the phone so that the USB-C is at a slight angle to get it to charge at all. Meanwhile, the absurdly short cords still work fine, so I know it's this cord and not my devices.It's not a bad price, and maybe other cords would also fail after about a year. But I was disappointed and won't be buying this again anytime soon.

text: This is a slow USB 2.0 cable, meant primarily for charging, but this is expected. The cable itself is stiffer that I'd have liked, but it is very hard to find a soft cable these days, even for cables with fewer required wires, such as USB 2.0 cables, with only four wires.I compared several A-to-C charging cables that I know, using the same phone, the same Anker charger. This cable delivered the lowest current to the phone (slowest to charge). The Type-C connector is of low quality. When inserted, it feels like it scratches the internals of the phone port, it is nothing like the original, high-quality connectors from LG, Google or Apple with their smooth but secure click feel.On top of that, Amazon shipped a single cable while I ordered two. The one that got shipped was a used cable in a resealed box. There was a visible traces of a sharp bend near the larger connector.The cable works, but I will not buy it again and do not recommend it.

text: Item itself is excellent for those looking for a reliable charging cable.  It is important to note this is a USB 2.0 cable, so look at something faster if you need to do Alternate Mode (such as video) or if you want SuperSpeed.  If you just need a solid, reliable and economical charging cable, this is it for you!  Bonus, they are USB-IF certified.Build quality is acceptable, but I did expect more from an amazon basic product.  The charger cable feels solid and smooth (no rough edges).  Purchased this set as it was highly touted by reviews.  However, you can see from the images I included that the plastic sleeve covering the USB C end can slip if not enough pressure is applied when unplugging your devices.  My cables were purchased used as an Amazon Warehouse deal.  I would suspect this to not be a problem if I purchased my cable new.Tldr, I highly recommend these cables if you are looking for something to charge your devices and occasionally transfer files.

Again, every single cord I bought had this issue, so it is a problem with the cord itself, and they do work but you have to sort of position your cord in a manner so your phone will actually charge. text: This cord broke within a few days of use, and I did not manhandle it. When I unplugged my phone after charging it one day, the metal piece that plugs into my phone broke off the cord and got stuck inside the phone, where it remains stuck to this day. My phone now only charges using a wireless charger. This means I can no longer charge it using a portable charger, which I relied on while traveling, and I also cannot use a car charger. It really bothers me that Amazon sells a piece of equipment that is so poorly made, it can potentially ruin an electronic device's charging port. I'm lucky that wireless charging is an option, because there is no way I would have been able to afford an entirely new phone due to a destroyed charger port.
